quotes.quote: Vyasa: The universe is both manifest and unmanifest, the eternal Brahma, beyond existence and non-existence, the source of all creation.
quotes.sanskrit: ऋतमेकाक्षरं ब्रह्म व्यक्ताव्यक्तं सनातनम्। असच्च सच्चैव च यद्विश्वं सदसतः परम्।
quotes.meaning: This verse describes the nature of Brahma (the ultimate reality) as both manifest (visible) and unmanifest (invisible), transcending dualities of existence and non-existence.
quotes.lore_snippet: The sages teach that reality is both seen and unseen, like the roots beneath a mighty tree. To perceive only the visible is to grasp but half the truth of existence.

quotes.quote: The ancient wisdom is the light in darkness, the imperishable seed from which all creation springs forth.
quotes.meaning: This describes how divine knowledge emerged in primordial darkness as the indestructible source (symbolized by the cosmic egg) of all beings.
quotes.lore_snippet: Even in the void before time, the spark of wisdom existed. The greatest sages understand that light first shines within before it illuminates the world.

quotes.quote: Hrishikesha (Vishnu) is the lord of all moving and unmoving beings, the pure and auspicious one worthy of all homage.
quotes.sanskrit: मङ्गल्यं मङ्गलं विष्णुं वरेण्यमनघं शुचिम्। नमस्कृत्य हृषीकेशं चराचरगुरुं हरिम्।
quotes.meaning: A reverential acknowledgment of Vishnu as the supreme deity who governs all creation and is the essence of auspiciousness.
quotes.lore_snippet: The wise bow to the cosmic guardian whose presence turns all paths auspicious. Where Vishnu's feet tread, chaos finds order.
